metadata.title: Radiculopathy, Cervical
description: A condition typically involving the compression of a nerve root by a herniated disk, osteophytes, inflammation, or a space-occupying  lesion(17) that reduces the size of the intervertebral foramen. It can also be caused by inflammation of the nerve root due to traction injuries or inflammation of surrounding tissue. The result is pain and motor and/or sensory deficits in the neck and ipsilateral upper extremity that will vary depending on the involved nerve root.(1,2) The average annual age-adjusted  incidence of cervical radiculopathy is 83.2 per 100,000 persons.(16,17) Men are affected more than women and it is most common in the 5th and 6th decades(17)

ICD-10 codes.G55.1: nerve root and plexus compressions in intervertebral disc disorders
ICD-10 codes.M54.1: radiculopathy (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. However, use caution with nonfinalized cases of workers’ compensation and third-party  insurance claims
presentation signs and symptoms: Neck pain, usually unilateral(1) –Pain usually increases with motions that reduce the size of the ipsilateral foramen (i.e., rotation and extension towards the painful side)
Upper extremity pain radiating into the nerve distribution of the affected nerve root(2)
Upper extremity motor function and sensory loss might be present even when pain is absent(2)
Loss of cervical ROM is common Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Cervical radiculopathy cases involve foraminal encroachment of the spinal nerve due tospondylosis, inflammation, or age-related  disk height changes.(18) However, this processdevelops very slowly and thus is less likely to occur in younger populations(1,2)–Degeneration, as found by MRI, is the most common mechanism of cervical rootirritation in older patients
Disk herniation onto the involved nerve usually occurs in the younger population
pathogenesis: The mechanism of radicular pain is still poorly understood. Furthermore, it has been shown that compression alone cannotresult in pain unless the dorsal root ganglion is also involved
Increased permeability of the membrane of the dorsal root ganglia with respect to the surrounding nerve root membrane isalso hypothesized as a source of radicular pain
risk factors: Trauma or repetitive activities, especially lifting of more than 25 pounds

overall contraindications precautions: Refer back to physician if symptoms and clinical findings suggest myelopathy (i.e., clumsiness of upper or lower limbs, urinary urgency, frequent falls, hyperreflexia, positive Babinski test).(2) See Clinical Review…Cervical Compressive Myelopathy ; CINAHL Topic ID: T708511
Avoid use of cervical collar for more than 1–2 weeks to prevent atrophy of cervical musculature
Age younger than 20 or older than 50 might be suggestive of another disorder(2)
It is important to respect the patient’s subjective complaints of pain during evaluation and treatment
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management for his or her symptoms. How has the pain responded to treatments?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective? Opioids, NSAIDs, muscle relaxants (e.g., cyclobenzaprine [Flexeril]), antidepressants (e.g., venlafaxine [Effexor]), and analgesics might be prescribed for this condition(2)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
X-ray  to assess for a decrease in disk height, osteophytes, gross spondylolisthesis, tumors, and fractures

MRI to detect a herniated disk pathology(2) is suggested for confirmation in patients who have failed a course of conservative therapy and who might be candidates for surgical treatment or intervention(4)
EMG to distinguish between cervical radiculopathy and peripheral nerve entrapment(2)
EMG is recommended in patients with unusual or atypical symptoms and in those with multifocal causes(5)
Ultrasound can be used to diagnose cervical radiculopathy based upon the cross-sectional  area of affected nerve roots(32)
Nerve roots with larger cross-sectional  areas suggests cervical radiculopathy
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice, heating pack, home traction unit) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: What makes the patient’s symptoms better or worse?
history of present illness.body chart: Body chart -Use a body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Patients with cervical radiculopathy often have unilateral neck pain that radiates into the upper extremity on the same side.(2) Upper trapezius and scapular pain are common in many patients regardless of the level of the nerve root compression; the pain might not radiate past the shoulder girdle(1) -Cervical radiculopathy patterns that might occur(1) -C2  posterior occipital headaches, temporal pain -C3  occipital headache, retro-orbital  or retroauricular pain -C4  base of neck, pain in the trapezius muscle -C5  pain in the lateral arm -C6  radial forearm pain, thumb and index finger pain -C7  pain in the 2nd finger -C8  pain in the 3rd and 4th fingers -T1  ulnar forearm pain
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). Are the symptoms getting better or worse?
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. In what positions(s) does the patient tend to sleep? How many or what type of pillows does he or she use?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any previous problems of, surgery of, or injury to the neck, shoulder, or arm?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, osteoporosis, and orthopedic disorders. Does patient have a history of anxiety?(18)Fibromyalgia?(22)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing Fever, unexplained weight loss, night pain Migraines Dizziness Tinnitus Fear-avoidance  beliefs(18)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -What type of work does the patient do? -How is the patient’s work area set up? Are modifications necessary? -Any activities or hobbies performed at home? -Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? -Half of patients with cervical radiculopathy are inactive during both summer and winter months. Additionally, half are overweight(18)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Note limitations and any modifications that might be necessary
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, sleep position/pillows, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Might be affected in extreme cases. Assess standing balance if patient reports falls or if cervical myelopathy is suspected. Use a standardized test such as the Berg Balance Scale as indicated
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pulses and capillary filling and compare with any skin color or temperature irregularities Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity –Evaluate upper limb neurodynamic mobility to help discern between a cervical radiculopathy and a peripheral nerve entrapment –When appropriate, assess cranial nerve integrity to assist in determining if signs or symptoms are due to another underlying condition needing referral (e.g., malignancy)Does the patient use compensatory motions or faulty cervical postures during functional tasks? Would the patient benefit from an ergonomic evaluation of his or her work station or home computer?
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess functional mobility, as indicated, using standardized tool such as FIMAssess vertebral joint mobility and mobility of related joints of the shoulder and upper extremity as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Evaluation of cervical and upper extremity strength is important, as motor weakness is considered a classic diagnostic finding for cervical radiculopathy –Researchers found that patients with cervical radiculopathy showed altered neck muscle endurance, muscular imbalance from side to side, and higher fatigue than healthy subjects on isometric holds/neck muscle endurance testing(19) –Assess cervical spine and bilateral upper extremity strength(2) -C5 – shoulder abduction and elbow flexion -C6 – elbow flexion and wrist extension -C7 – elbow extension and wrist flexion -C8 – finger flexors -T1 – hand intrinsics –Lesions of the upper cervical roots are rare and usually present with no motor loss –Assess grip strength with a hand dynamometer
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess and note all abnormalities throughout spine, head, and shoulders (e.g., rounded shoulders, thoracic kyphosis, forward head posture)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess all cervical spine motions and upper extremity motions
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Reflex testing –Evaluation of deep tendon reflexes. Hyporeflexia may suggest cervical radiculopathy –Uncover any hyporeflexia consistent with involved roots; biceps/brachioradialis (C5, C6), triceps (C6, C7, C8) Self-care/ADLs  (objective testing) –Inquire about or evaluate ADLs. Are ADLs affected by patient’s pain and/or weakness or restricted ROM (e.g., turning head for safe driving)?
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Assess for any sensation changes in the neck and extremities and, if present, determine if they follow a particular dermatomal pattern. Decreased or loss of sensation is indicative of cervical radiculopathy
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –Spurling (maneuver) test (may also be referred to as the quadrant test) -Laterally flexing the neck towards the symptomatic side when the patient is seated and then applying an axial load of approximately 7 kg.(6) A positive test reproduces or exacerbates the symptomsWhile seated, the patient places the hand of symptomatic side on head. A positive test reduces or eliminates symptoms of radiculopathyWith the patient in supine, the therapist grasps the patient’s chin and occiput, flexes the neck to a position of comfort, and slowly applies a distraction force up to 14 kg. A positive test reduces or eliminates symptomsA seated patient is instructed to take a deep breath and hold it as he or she slowly exhales for 2–3 seconds. A positive test is a reproduction of symptomsA sequence of movements with patient in supine that can test median, radial, or ulnar nerve bias. A positive result is unilateral and indicative of cervical radiculopathy
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Assess for signs of lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions (e.g., weakness, muscle wasting, hypotonicity, or hyporeflexia) and upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions (hypertonicity, hyperreflexia, clonus, positive Babinski sign, unsteady gait). Cervical compressive myelopathy may present with LMN signs at the level of the lesion and UMN signsT708511 for more information)

contraindications precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold might be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Where heat rubs or liniments have been recently used
In patients with cognitive deficits or if a language barrier exists
Rheumatoid arthritis or other acute inflammatory diseases
Conditions or diseases that cause increased joint laxity (e.g., Down syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos  syndrome)
Cardiac or respiratory insufficiency (inversion and mechanical traction for lumbar spine)
In patients whose symptoms increase with traction
Temporomandibular joint dysfunction (cervical traction with a chin strap)
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Traction  contraindications(7) (Please see Clinical Review…Traction, Mechanical [Cervical] ; CINAHL Topic ID:T709273 for more information)
Traction  precautions(7) (Please see Clinical Review…Traction, Mechanical [Cervical] , referenced above for more information)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Treatment is necessary if there is pain, weakness, decreased ROM/flexibility, decreased function, poor posture, and/or faulty body mechanics
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Shoulder pathology(2) Myelopathy – A subset of radiculopathy patients present with weakness alone without significant pain or sensory symptoms, making it important to investigate for myelopathy –Deficits of fine motor skills, poor balance, and bowel and bladder dysfunction are typically not found in cervical radiculopathy but do occur in cervical myelopathy –Researchers in South Korea found that 51.9% of patients with myelopathy also presented with radiculopathic symptoms/ presentation.(28) This demonstrates the possibility of having combined cervical myelopathy and radiculopathy, thus stressing the importance of identifying the defining characteristics of each condition Peripheral nerve entrapment syndromes (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome, cubital tunnel syndrome)(2) Parsonage-Turner  syndrome (neuralgic amyotrophy) Malignancy (e.g., lymphoma, carcinomatous meningitis) Infection (e.g., herpes zoster, HIV , cytomegalovirus, Lyme disease) Thoracic outlet syndrome Pancoast tumor Coronary artery disease and cholecystitis, which might cause referred pain to the upper extremity(2) Vertebral artery dissection(24) Polymyalgia rheumatica Lateral pectoral nerve injury/lesion(23)
prognosis: Although most patients improve, some patients have persistent or worsening symptoms and require surgery(5)
When conservative treatments fail, surgery improves signs and symptoms in most patients(5)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Patients might be referred to a spine or pain management specialist if intractable pain does not respond to 6 weeks of conservative treatment(2) Neurologist for persistent radicular or neurological symptoms Psychology for patients with difficulty dealing with the pain and/or disability Acupuncturist for alternative pain management
other considerations: Research regarding the use and effectiveness of steroid injections is conflicting

Epidural steroid injection is typically considered a safe and effective treatment to try before undergoing surgery(8) –It should not be a first-line  treatment and should be considered only in conjunction with a comprehensive rehabilitation treatment plan.(9) Consideration must be given to potential complications,(4) such as spinal infarct –In a prospective study conducted in South Korea, in more than 80% of 98 patients with cervical radiculopathy who were surgical candidates surgery was avoided using epidural steroid injection(8,20) -In a follow-up  study, injections were less effective for patients with paresthesia without pain(20)

Authors of a 2015 study showed that only a minority of patients with disk herniation or spondylosis and proven nerve root compression benefit from cervical transforaminal injections of steroids(21) –48 patients were included in the study –Only 35.4% of patients achieved at least a 50% reduction in pain after treatment –22.9% of the patients ended up undergoing surgery

Authors of a 2015 study showed positive results for injections of autologous conditioned serum (ACS) versus methylprednisolone (MPD) in unilateral cervical radiculopathy patients(25) –ACS is an orthobiologic derived from the patient’s own blood –Forty patients were selected for either ACS or MPD injections under image guidance into the perineural area of affected nerve root –Six-month  follow-up  revealed ACS patients to have equally good or better results than MPD patients. While additional research is required, these results provide another option for treatment prior to surgical intervention

Surgical interventions include discectomy, laminectomy, foraminotomy, fusion, and disk replacement(5) –Researchers in India looked at pain outcomes in patients with short-  and long-term  complaints prior to surgical treatment. Patients with shorter duration of symptoms prior to surgical intervention (ACDF) had better improvement in radicular symptoms and increased reduction in pain scores(27)
treatment summary: Many physical therapy interventions have been proposed and utilized in treating patients with cervical radiculopathy. These treatments have included mechanical traction, manual therapy, therapeutic exercise, and pain modalities. However, there is very limited evidence of the effectiveness of specific physical therapy interventions(4) –Results of many nonrandomized studies but few randomized trials have suggested that conservative intervention might be as effective as surgery

Researchers of a 2015 study suggest that manual therapy and exercise are effective in reducing pain and functional limitations related to cervical radiculopathy(17) –Adding manual techniques thought to increase the size of intervertebral foramen showed no additional benefits –Participants showed improvement on NDI, QuickDASH, and numeric pain-rating  scale scores

Authors of a 2016 systematic review of manual therapy in the treatment of cervical radiculopathy reported that there is limited evidence in the literature to support using manual therapy techniques to improve function, increase active ROM, and decrease pain and disability(10) –Four RCTs met inclusion criteria –Manual therapy techniques included muscle energy techniques, non-thrust/thrust  manipulation/mobilization of the cervical and/or thoracic spine, soft tissue mobilization, and neural mobilization –A definitive progression for treating cervical radiculopathy with manual physical therapy has not been developed -High-quality  RCTs are needed to establish protocols
Electrotherapeutic modalities –There are no studies showing the long-term  benefit of electrical stimulation, ultrasound, or TENS for pain control(1)

Cervical collar –The cervical collar might help decrease nerve root inflammation and decrease muscle spasm. Also, the warmth from wearing the collar might lessen pain(1) –Wearing the collar backwards might help to increase the size of the neuroforamina by promoting flexion of the neck(1) –Use of a cervical collar is not recommended for more than 1–2weeks as prolonged immobilization might cause atrophy of the cervical musculature(1)

Cervical traction –Cervical traction for cervical radiculopathy can be effective in reducing pain and improving disability(11,29) –There is inconsistent, high-quality  evidence suggesting that the use of intermittent cervical traction along with strengthening exercises is more effective in decreasing neck pain in patients with cervical radiculopathy versus strength training alone.(31) Additional research is needed to determine long-term  effectiveness –Researchers conducting an RCT in South Korea found that neural mobilization along with mechanical traction may be more effective than traction alone in decreasing pain, increasing function, and improving deep neck flexor muscle endurance(33)

Therapeutic exercises/posture reeducation –Based upon research evidence, stabilization exercise training may be an effective treatment choice for decreasing pain, improving function, and improving posture in patients with cervical radiculopathy(30)

Manipulation –Cervical manipulation has historically not been recommended in patients with cervical radiculopathy.(1) The impetus for this has been the lack of evidence demonstrating efficacy in treating patients with cervical radiculopathy along with documented rare complications(2) –However, researchers of a 2015 systematic review and meta-analysis  found moderate-level  evidence to support the use of cervical spine manipulation in the treatment of patients with cervical radiculopathy(26) -Three RCTs with 502 participants with degenerative cervical radiculopathy were included -Meta-analysis  showed cervical spine manipulation improved V AS pain scores immediately -These studies did not evaluate safety or adverse effects of cervical spine manipulation –Although there is limited evidence that chiropractic manipulation is effective in treating cervical radiculopathy,(12) at this time manipulation is not recommended(2)

Multimodal treatment approach –A combination of manual therapy and therapeutic exercise might be more effective in treating patients with cervical radiculopathy than either intervention alone based on a study in which patients were randomized to 1 of 3 treatment groups(13) –In 2015, researchers in China conducted an overview of systematic reviews regarding the effect of complementary and alternative medicine(CAM) in cervical radiculopathy(16) -CAM included acupuncture, manual therapy, and cervical spine manipulation -All of the systematic reviews studied showed CAM intervention was superior to control groups -Majority of systematic reviews used low to moderate quality methodology . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Cervical pain with or without upper extremity radicular symptomsDecrease pain _ Eliminate or centralize upper extremity symptomsPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Cryotherapy and heat packs for short-term pain relief(7) _ Mechanical intermittent cervical traction for reducing pain and disability(3) _ Posture correction _ _

maintenance or prevention: Education on lifestyle change and how to modify tasks that increase the pain
Prescribe home exercises that address impairments and encourage patient to perform throughout the day
